page.title: 05NORTH YORK MOORS NAT.PARK
page.content: The North York Moors Nat.Park is famous for its magnificant scenery. Many walkers frequent the area and some of the paths used date back to pre-historic times.The Drove road was used by men from Scotland as they drove their cattle to markets in the south.They would climb the Cleveland hills at Scarth NickG.R.474004 where there is a natural gap in the hills. Keeping to the high dry land,they would travel along the hills to Sutton Bank.The Drove road is still used today by farmers to move their sheep from one area of moorland to another.Two well-known footpaths pass through the area,the Cleveland Way and the Lyke Wake Walk.Other visitors come in cars and SheepwashG.R.471994 is a popular picnic place at weekends and holiday times.Varying amenties are provided within the area for visitors.
